prompt:
Am I in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for ending free friend rides in my car?
My friend always hops rides everywhere in my car. I fill up the tank and pick him up at his house and drop him back off safely at home. This past weekend he put 10 in gas because I forgot my purse home and yesterday he asked me back for it. He has ridden in my car hundreds of times without putting gas. Am I an asshole for saying find your way around in the future?
"""

Am I in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (I am in the wrong) and B for No (I am not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The person is asking if they're an asshole for ending free rides for their friend. The friend has ridden in their car hundreds of times without contributing to gas. This time, the friend put in $10 for gas because the person forgot their purse. Then the person said the friend should find their way around in the future.

Hmm. So the main issue is whether the person is being fair by stopping the rides. The friend didn't contribute to gas before, so maybe the person was covering all the costs. Now that the friend tried to help once, the person is ending the arrangement. 

Wait, but the person ended it after the friend put in $10. Maybe they felt it wasn't enough? Or maybe they were just tired of covering all the gas costs. The friend might have expected to keep riding for free, but the person is now holding them accountable. 

Is the person in the wrong? Well, if the friend was using their car without contributing, the person isn't obligated to provide rides. They can set boundaries. So maybe the person isn't in the wrong. But maybe the friend felt they were helping by putting in $10, so the person's response was a bit abrupt. 

But the person is the one who owns the car and is paying for gas. They have the right to decide who rides with them and under what conditions. If the friend was taking advantage of the situation by not contributing, the person is justified in ending it. So probably answer B, No.
